Pete,
I can't think of anything in English better than the Tsuba Geijutsu-K=
o by Toigoye and Haynes.  I'm sure that there is further commentary in Joly=
's translations of Akiyama republished in the NCJSC newsletters some years =
ago, but I don't have them organized or indexed.

Nobuie Tsuba by Nakamura =
is as good a picture sources as any, at least for having large numbers of e=
xamples to compare.  Each mei is attributed to a type in the text of the os=
higata section.  The attribution is usually at or near the end of the text =
(lower left portion).  
=E6=94=BE=E3=82=8C=E9=8A=98 hanare-mei, =E5=A4=AA=
=E5=AD=97=E9=8A=98 futoji- mei, =E8=A9=B0=E3=82=8A=E9=8A=98 sumari-mei, =E5=
=B7=A6=E5=82=BE=E9=8A=98 sakei-mei and =E7=94=B2=E8=83=83=E9=8A=98 katchu-m=
ei are ones I saw frequently when I flipped through the book.  

In the pas=
t there were something like 8 or more categories of mei in use.  Most signa=
tures these days are lumped into futoji-mei and hanare-mei.  There's quite =
a bit of variability among accepted examples in each category though, so th=
ings are still not simple.  Wakayama shows some details about the different=
 signatures in the first volume of his Toso Kodogu Koza.  No doubt there ar=
e other comparisons in the various survey books.

It's a difficult area.

J=
im



  Would anyone know of a source for explaination/differentiation of t=
he

e 
  never been able to find the reference in English.
  Thanks much!
  Pet=
